text: I have recently completed my doctoral studies in Prof.~Peter~M√ºller's Programming Methodology Group at ETH~Zurich. My current focus is on developing scalable and precise automated formal reasoning techniques and programmer-friendly tools for formal verification.
Before joining ETH in~2015, I have been Research Scientist at Intel's Strategic~CAD~Labs, working on tools for automatically debugging power and performance bugs in Android.

Prior to that, I was a member of a compiler R&D project at Intel, where I applied machine learning for automatically tuning compiler optimizations and designed novel optimizations for an explicitly parallel computer architecture.
I hold a MSc degree in Computer Science and a BSc degree in Applied Mathematics and Physics, both from MIPT, Russia.

children.name: News!
text: üéì I have completed my doctoral thesis: Compositional Verification of Rich Program Properties in Separation Logic. The thesis consists of three parts. Part~I presents a technique for compositional reasoning about set~comprehensions~‚Äî aggregation expressions over heap-based data structures. Part~II extends this setting to compositional reasoning about local reachability properties of heap-manipulating programs. Part~III develops an automatic verification debugging technique that lifts SMT models to counterexample heap diagrams.

üìú Check out our new FM'21 paper titled Identifying Overly Restrictive Matching Patterns in SMT-based Program Verifiers. This work develops the idea of generating triggering terms for mitigating incompleteness in tools like Viper and Dafny.

children.name: Viper
text: I used to be a member of the team developing Viper, an intermediate language and the infrastructure for SMT-automated deductive formal verification. My focus was on extending Viper's specification features, enabling modular verification of heap reachability and comprehensions (data structure aggregations). Additionally, I used to be the maintainer of Viper~IDE.
